title: Melissa Morales
text:
Hey there! I’m Melissa. I am an ecologist and environmental science researcher focused on advancing our understanding of ecological systems through fieldwork, data analysis, and scientific writing. My experience spans pollinator ecology, insect biology, and environmental data science, including safely leading field crews, conducting large-scale ecological surveys in U.S. national parks, and developed sampling and analysis methods. I bring skills in plot and transect surveys, flora and fauna identification, soil and water quality assessments, and grant and permit writing. I have coauthored peer-reviewed publications and technical reports that address species interactions, community dynamics, and ecosystem change.
As a problem solver in the office, field, and lab, I thrive in dynamic environments that require adaptability, collaboration, and creative solutions. I am eager to expand my skill set and connect with researchers dedicated to rigorous ecological research and effective science communication.

title: About Me
text:
I’m originally from New York City, though my curiosity about the natural world truly flourished after my family moved to the Poconos. Long hikes in state parks, observing wildlife, and volunteering at events like BioBlitzes sparked a passion for exploring ecosystems and understanding how humans interact with the environment. Early experiences with the National Park Service at Delaware Water Gap helped me build skills in science communication and public engagement, setting the foundation for my career in ecology.
My academic and professional path has taken me from Northampton Community College to earning a B.S. in Environmental Science at Moravian College, and now to graduate research at Colorado State University. I’ve led international field crews, conducted insect surveys, and developed innovative sampling and analysis methods. My work has allowed me to hone practical field and lab techniques, navigate complex ecological research projects, and contribute to both scientific publications and community-focused initiatives, including drafting a Local Climate Action Plan for Upper Darby Township.
Outside of research, I love hiking, paddling, and camping, as well as exploring museums, listening to vinyls, going to theatres, and reading. Whether in the field, lab, or office, I’m energized by problem-solving, collaboration, and discovering ways to connect people with the natural world.
